Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to stimulate and actively develop research on algebraic stacks. Algebraic stacks are widely used, especially for thinking about moduli spaces, and are one of the most important tools in algebraic geometry today. The research will focus on foundational questions and open questions related to global geometric problems. Two questions are: How far can you get developing the theory with a minimal set of hypotheses? In what generality can we develop intersection theory for algebraic stacks? Two geometric open problems are: Which algebraic stacks are quotient stacks? Are the Brauer group and the cohomological Brauer group of a separated scheme of finite type over a field the same?

The principal investigator will visit mathematics departments and give talks to advertise these problems. The principal investigator will attack some of the research problems, and collaborate on others with graduate students, post-docs, and algebraic geometers in the international mathematical community. As an integral part of the proposal the principal investigator will maintain a web-based collaborative algebraic geometry project, called the "Stacks Project." The goal is to develop and document theory, with the aim of closing the gap between graduate education and current research. The stacks project intends to be partly a high level text book, partly a foundational reference on algebraic stacks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is the project outcomes report on the NSF grant ``Foundations of Algebraic Stacks''. The Principal Investigator (PI) of this award, Professor Johan de Jong, collaborated with graduate students, post-docs, as well as other researchers on topics having to do with algebraic stacks and their foundations. As an important part of this work, the PI maintained and improved the Stacks Project (see below).

 

In algebraic geometry we study spaces, i.e., geometric objects, which can be defined using polynomial equations. Often our spaces are endowed with additional structures, analogous to how in the real world an object isn't just defined by its dimensions, but it comes with attributes such as color, density, etc.  An algebraic stack is a kind of twisted space. On an algebraic stack, the additonal structure isn't just an attribute, but rather it is a way of very precisely saying how we've locally twisted the space (usually by a group action) to obtain not quite a space but a stack. To set this up precisely requires a quite formidable abstract machinery (see below) and a lot of higher mathematics. It turns out that these algebraic stacks occur very naturally once you start studying classical algebraic geometry objects, such as algebraic curves. Namely, it turns out the collection of all algebraic curves in some very precise sense forms an algebraic stack and indeed this is how the first algebraic stack was discovered by Deligne and Mumford.

 

The PI and collaborators are documenting the abstract machinery and mathematical foundations mentioned above in an online project, namely the Stacks project . This is a very long term, massively collaborative, ever ongoing project in the form of an open source textbook and reference work on algebraic geometry specifically aimed at foundations for algebraic stacks. Serious readers can leave comments and there is a system in place to reference the results in the mathematical literature, e.g., published papers. Keeping this in mind, the major outcome of the NSF award for which this is the outcomes report, is that during the period of the award enough background material and general theory was added to define and prove all basic properties of the Deligne-Mumford stack classifying algebraic curves mentioned above.
